div.head: Chapter 2
Whether power should ever be resisted.
div.p:
Here arises a question not to be passed over in silence. For it has been said above, that the power of sinning and harming is given to man or the devil only by God.
The Apostle
however says, that
he who resists authority, resists the ordinance of God . Therefore, since the devil has the power of evil, by God's ordinance, it seems that his power ought not to be resisted.

But it must be known that the Apostle is speaking there of secular power, namely of kings and princes and the like; who are not to be resisted in those things which God commands to be rendered to them, namely in tributes and the like. But if any prince or devil should command or persuade anything contrary to God, then resistance must be made.

Hence
Augustine , determining when power should be resisted,
in the book On the Nature of the Good , says:
If a power commands what you ought not to do, then surely despise the power, fearing the greater power. Consider the very grades of human affairs. If a curator commands something, should it be done, if he commands contrary to the proconsul? Again, if the proconsul himself commands one thing, and the emperor commands another, is there any doubt that the former should be disregarded and service rendered to the latter? Therefore if the emperor commands one thing, and God another, the former being disregarded, God must be obeyed
.
